thread.title_full: Carlton: Steve Patterson provided blueprint of what not to do as Texas athletic director | Dallas Morning News

author: Chuck Carlton
title: Carlton: Steve Patterson provided blueprint of what not to do as Texas athletic director
text:
In the end, Steve Patterson was more arrogant than what even Texas could stand.
Somehow Patterson achieved what many thought impossible in 22 months as the school's athletic director, a key reason he's out of a job today.
Yes, his predecessor DeLoss Dodds was accused rightly of arrogance many times in 32 years. But Dodds almost always was arrogant about Texas and its success and its wallet. Keeping up with the Joneses? Texas was the Joneses, Dodds famously proclaimed. His talk targeted Aggies or Sooners or Cornhuskers or other conferences.
He treated his own fan base with a folksy charm, a wink and nod. When football kept winning and winning under Mack Brown and other sports thrived too, it was all good.
Patterson was arrogant about, well, Patterson. He gave the impression of being the smartest guy in the room, even if that wasn't the case. Patterson might have worn a nifty burnt orange sports coat, but at heart he was a green eyeshade guy.
During a conference call on Tuesday, new Texas President Greg Fenves said many view athletics "as the front door the university" and he wanted to make it a "welcoming front door."
For many, that front door came equipped with a toll booth, thanks to Patterson.
Yes, Texas probably needed to tighten its belt at the end of Dodds' tenure. With cost of attendance and possible name/image/likeness legal decisions, every athletic department is looking for extra revenue, including Texas.
Under Patterson, though, Texas went from the Joneses to the Joads from the Grapes of Wrath .
Every dollar was precious and had to be squeezed from fans or athletic budgets. One-hour plane flights for teams became long bus rides.
In a lot of ways, his time at Texas resembled the horror stories that emerged from his time running the Portland Trail Blazers.
As Patterson departed, Texas selected former Darrell Royal linebacker turned attorney Mike Perrin as its interim AD. By all accounts, he's smart and well-liked and knows the landscape as well as anyone.
Fenves said he was looking forward to working Perrin "in developing and improving our relationship with Longhorn Nation."
Perrin probably doesn't need any advice, especially from sportswriters. He was an academic standout during his Texas days.
Maybe the best thing he could be is the anti-Patterson.
There's even a handy blueprint.
Michigan took a gamble on former Domino's executive Dave Brandon as athletic director just as Texas did on Patterson. Brandon spent four years alienating a fan base every bit as proud and devoted as Texas' fan base. The parallels between Brandon and Patterson are striking.
Brandon was sent packing last season, and Michigan hired a former Bo Schembechler player and former Steelcase executive named Jim Hackett.
He managed to land Jim Harbaugh, and Michigan fans started filling up the Big House again.
Earlier this year, Michigan negotiated a deal with Nike through 2027 that will pay the Wolverines $169 million in equipment and apparel rights.
Texas is facing similar negotiation right now, with that apparently on Perrin's plate.
It's also interesting that Hackett is now in his 11th month with the interim tag.
Fenves declined to provide a timetable for a search for a new AD, which could include anyone from NCAA executive Oliver Luck to Louisville AD Tom Jurich to countless others.
Maybe Texas fans should get used to Perrin for the near future.

(Eric Gay/AP)
